Inside the house quiet noises; the swish of a scrubbing b stone; a rocking chair creaking to and fro; a knife chopp CLOSE ON: A kitchen knife, sharp-edged, pitted black, sli through white-green onion rings, juice flecking the blade Slivers of onion pile up on a dark wood chopping board, t threads of yellow-green in the white. Reflected for a mom before the blade sweeps them away.

A handsome Dutch town house, red-brick, three storeys hig The front door opens and a MAN and WOMAN come out. His cl are dark and fine, his face half-hidden by a wide hat. Sh ripely pregnant, her belly large against the swathes of h velvet dress. She leans on his arm for support, but still the way.
As they walk through the prosperous town they are greeted bowed to: people of consequence. He nods, she smiles and to acquaintances, blonde curls dancing.
Splitting a red cabbage, exposing the white veins between purple leaves. A GIRL’S hand, small and deft, places the by the onion.

The couple cross a bridge over the canal, turn into narro streets, poorer houses tightly-packed. WOMEN in white cap aprons over dark clothes look up from scrubbing front doo steps, WORKING MEN raise their hats. He still nods, she i them. A BOY (FRANS) leans on the bridge, watching from under a blond curls. The moment they are gone he is off - racing the street, cutting through an alleyway to get ahead of t November 2003
In the kitchen his sister, GRIET, reacts to the sound of door; eyes wide, lips parted. Anticipation, uncertainty, fear. A look we will come to recognise.

Mother! GRIET pulls the stiff folds of her white cap further forw round her face, resumes her work. She is slight, a young but with a sureness to her movements which seems older. H clothes are as plain and severe as the narrow Calvinist r the fresh-cut vegetables the only stroke of colour. She s carrots onto the dish, absorbed in the pattern she is cre Her MOTHER comes hurrying into the room in her starched b clothes. A brief, irritated glance at the dish.
Leave that. GRIET puts down the knife carefully.
GRIET hurries up narrow stairs to a room under the eaves, even she must stoop. Only a shaft of light penetrates the In the darkest corner a MAN hunches in a rocking chair.
Father. GRIET squats in front of him. We see his hand is badly disfigured, fingers twisted into a claw, skin taut and sh pink in places, otherwise ridged and gnarled.

The Guild Master... He nods, face in shadow. This is an expected event. There is a silent understanding between them. GRIET place best black jacket on the bed, guides his hand with her sp fingers. After a moment he stops her, instead he searches with fum fingers on a shelf by the bed. There are several tiles pr there, blue figures on white. He feels for one in particu A girl and boy, hand in hand. The unmistakable line of GR cap, FRANS flinging an arm joyfully in the air. He presses it into GRIET'S hands, a gesture of regret and apology. November 2003
The handsome couple stop at a small house. Now they have the WOMAN hesitates, suddenly nervous. Her HUSBAND tidies strand of her hair then knocks at the door.

From below the WOMAN’S VOICE; over-loud, her heels clatte the tiled floor. GRIET‘S FATHER lifts his head - the first full sight of h face, taut and twisted, as if it had been melted and re-s eyes scarred and blind. Recent, terrible injuries. GRIET to ease on his coat. GRIET’S FATHER I cannot... (meet him).
Griet runs into position, cheeks flushed, and is once mor chopping the vegetables as her MOTHER leads in the visito

This is Griet. The MAN and WOMAN step down into the kitchen, crowding th narrow space. GRIET looks to her MOTHER for guidance, car with her work, head bent. The woman, CATHARINA, talks fast, distractedly, her hands forever moving, twisting the blonde curls on her neck.

She’s very small. You think she is strong enough? We can‘t have a girl who is always worn out and complaining. My mother is worried about her age. And she‘s never worked outside the home before. CATHARINA seems too large for the room, too opulent, a pe inlaid crucifix dangles heavily between her breasts.
She is strong. A good girl and willing.
All things considered I suppose it must do but there will have to be a trial. How long should it be, husband? He isn't listening, gazing abstractedly at the wall. CATH hurries on. November 2003

I don’t know, I can’t have someone in the house who won’t pull her weight. As it is I hardly...(can make ends meet.) There are all the children to think of too. My husband is Guild Master but we are under no obligation to do this. No obligation at all.
(Stony) She works hard. CATHARINA twists her necklace round her fingers. Maybe sh too far.
I mean to say we are sorry for your husband‘s misfortune. It was a fire?
The kiln exploded. Two men died. He was spared. CATHARINA crosses herself.
Deo gratias. GRIET‘S MOTHER stiffens at the Papist words. Uncomfortabl silence.
(At last) Aye, God be thanked.
(Brightly) Well, shall we say a month and if she proves satisfactory- (I will keep her on.)

What are you doing, Griet? The MAN'S voice cuts across his wife’s. GRIET looks up, startled. He is staring at the vegetables she has arrange swathes of colour on the dish. GRIET hesitates. Her MOTHE glares at her.
Cutting vegetables for soup, sir.
Why did you lay them out like that? His quietness is intense, his cool grey eyes hold hers.
I- I- Ready for the soup, sir. November 2003 CATHARINA snorts. GRIET is thrown; he has intruded into private world. Instinctively she pulls her cap forward.
(Gently) Is that the order they go in the pot?
No, sir. The MAN makes a small impatient gesture, her answers aren he wants. Her MOTHER is silently urging her. He picks up a piece of onion and turnip.
You have separated the whites. And the carrot and cabbage?
The colours fight each other.
Ah. His eyebrows go up, a small smile. GRIET finds she is ver pleased to have pleased him.
Is that how you spend your time - arranging vegetables?
(Alarmed) Oh no. Not at all. The MAN drops the shreds of onion and turnip, deliberatel careless. GRIET'S fingers move to rearrange them but she controls herself. The MAN is still watching.
She might clean my studio. His casual words are shocking to his wife. She gasps and too quickly, the heavy belly off-balance. The kitchen kni spins off the table and clatters on the ground.
Catharina! (Quietly) Be careful. GRIET bends to pick up the knife, crouching at his feet, face inches from the rich trim of his cloak.
Excuse me, Master Vermeer. November 2003
In the half dark GRIET neatly folds a chemise, two starch aprons, a woollen shawl, her prayer book. FRANS pretends sleep as she tiptoes out.

GRIET’S MOTHER pulls oat cakes from the griddle and burns hand. The only clue to her heartbreak. GRIET holds a wet rag to the burn. A rare moment of conta Recovering herself GRIET'S MOTHER folds the oat cakes int clean muslin.
The food may be strange to your stomach. How can she begin to tell her daughter all she needs to k

Keep clear of their Catholic prayers. Or if you must be with them when they pray, stop your ears. GRIET nods dutifully. Her MOTHER hesitates then reaches t back of the mantelpiece and brings down a tin box, the fa treasure chest. It contains some silver coins, a few lega papers and a tortoiseshell comb, prettily decorated but o

Had it from my mother, the day I was married. I never thought our family would come to this. (A beat) I hear the Master is a good man. She doesn’t know her own mind - someone should've stood up to her before now. She'd work you to death and not even notice. A silence. Abruptly she thrusts the comb and cakes at GRI
Go on then.

GRIET crosses the empty central square, at one end the gr fagade of the Town Hall, at the other the vast brick bulk New Church. A few stall holders are setting up. At the brick star in the middle of the square GRIET hesit She adjusts the bundle under her arm, squares her shoulde heads across the square into the unknown. She looks small lonely in the huge space. November 2003
GRIET walks along an unfamiliar street.

head_text.subj: EXT. VERMEER HOUSE, OUDE LANGENDIJCK DAY

text: On a bench outside sit four well-dressed GIRLS, one with BOY on her lap. Four pairs of watchful eyes assessing her silence. The oldest, MAERTGE (pronounced Mertha) holds a shell and pipe-stem. The youngest(LISBETH), clutching a r doll, pulls at MAERTGE'S sleeve impatiently. After a moment the next oldest, CORNELIA, a thin, quick c with bright red hair snatches them and blows a stream of bubbles. They float upwards, glistening in the sunshine.

Tell Tanneke the new maid is here. After a moment MAERTGE decides this is the right thing to The little ones run after her. GRIET and CORNELIA are lef alone. CORNELIA eyes GRIET, smirking at her heavy clothin clumsy shoes.
TANNEKE, the stolid servant of the house, leads the way, as she goes.

Young Mistress is out this morning. I’m to show you round. She sniffs, as if to say this is not a proper part of her duties. Her face is red from the stove, cheeks pocked. She indicates the water pump as she leads the way up the
Water for the table.
The WASHING KITCHEN has a big copper cauldron set over a There is a large heap of soiled laundry.

Take water from the canal for laundry, it’s clean enough this side of town. Soda, coppers, boiler, sand and soap. The middle of the room is full of sheets drying, careless arranged. Surreptitiously GRIET straightens the nearest s November 2003
Linen goes out to bleach in the sun. In here in bad weather. Flat irons, linen press, pressing table. Cooking kitchen... She sweeps on down the steps.
TANNEKE’S stronghold, dominated by the big cooking fire. and pans, none too clean, hang on the walls. TANNEKE care throws some onion skins in the grate.
You're to help serve and clear. Buy fish and Meat from the Market when Young Mistress don’t want to - and that’s often enough. She curves a hand out beyond her own substantial belly.
You'll take your meals with me and the children. Pewter and silver, needs polishing every week. She pulls on a rope and pulley to open a trapdoor down to cellar.
That's your sleeping place. Scour the pots and pans. Fetch in the milk and butter. No time to pause as TANNEKE leads the way through to anot room.

There are paintings hung thickly on every wall. GRIET is distracted by the dazzling variety of colour and images. Glancing up SHE SEES CORNELIA watching from the upstairs balcony. TANNEKE rattles off instructions.

Dust and polish the woodwork, beat the carpets, trim the candlewicks. Floor scrubbed morning and night. Young Mistress and Master sleep and have company here. The furniture is solid and intricately carved, the heavy curtains round the marriage bed richly brocaded. But dirt laundry, children’s shoes and toys lie scattered on the f disorderly and profuse, the opposite of GRIET'S clean, ba home. November 2003

Air the bedding, wash and press the sheets and linen, heat water for Young Mistress to bathe, empty the pots. TANNEKE stands with hands on hips, out of breath. Her apr grey and soiled with grease spots, her fingers reddened f work. CORNELIA comes and leans on TANNEKE, catlike in her temporary affection.
Have you been doing all this yourself, Tanneke? The cooking and cleaning and washing? The right words. TANNEKE puffs with grim pride.
Nobody but. Would've put paid to a scrawny creature like you - day in, day out. On top of all the errands bar the Draper and 'Pothec'ry. She looks around with proprietorial pride.
(Kinder) You’ll get used to it. CORNELIA notices GRIET staring at the paintings.
Do you like them? CORNELIA is looking up at her, alert and interested. GRIE smiles back.
Did your father do all these? CORNELIA laughs scornfully.
No! He just sells them. All his paintings go straight away. GRIET feels stupid, as she was meant to, but TANNEKE is a bustling out of the room, GRIET must hurry after.
This way.

head_text.subj: INT. GREAT HALL/MARIA THINS ROOM DAY

text: TANNEKE opens the door to a smaller but finely furnished She allows GRIET to glimpse inside. November 2003  10
My Mistress, Maria Thins has this room. 'Tis her owns the house - not her daughter, for all her fine airs. GRIET has an impression of gaudy Catholic paintings, fine and a prie-Dieu.
GRIET follows Tanneke’s broad back up the stairs. TANNEKE towards the door at the end of the corridor. In spite of she is frightened, her voice a whisper.
You're to clean in there. As GRIET takes a step in that direction.
(scandalised) Not now! He's painting.

Carrying a night light, GRIET goes carefully down the lad into the cellar. The glint of bottles and jars, a broken footstool, a child’s wooden top, the paint dim under laye dust. A sleeping place with a mattress, bolster and blanket has made on a low wooden shelf. GRIET arranges her few posses neatly: the prayer book and comb, her best lace collar, c and aprons, her father’s tile. Wearily she kneels to pray hands are already red and raw from all the work. She is a take off her cap when she stops, uneasy. She looks around dark room, shadows flickering in the candlelight. Suddenl sees a face, ghostly white. It is a Pleta; Mary holding the dead body of Christ, the Virgin's face hollow-eyed with grief, an arm raised in wi despair. GRIET looks at it uneasily. Then with a quick decisive mo she takes her spare apron and drapes it over the painting out her candle. Only the faintest glimmer of light comes the open trapdoor. In the dark she can hear noises from the household, the M low voice and laughter. She curls up into a ball.
With an effort GRIET heaves up a full pitcher of water an it into the washing copper. A fire blazes under the coppe GRIET wipes the sweat from her eyes. November 2003  11

GRIET scrubs at soiled linen on a washboard. There are we sheets hanging up, a huge pile still to do. Her fingers a from the washing soda and hot water. CATHARINA comes out, moving slowly with the weight of her Her chemise is already crumpled, she looks hot and tired, blonde curls damp on her neck. She watches GRIET working. turns and dips a curtsey.
Good Morning, Madam. CATHARINA looks annoyed.

Don’t speak till you’re spoken to. But she seems exhausted by this, continues to stand there absently, one hand on her belly, the other nervously jang the household keys which hang at her hip. GRIET takes a m shirt from the laundry basket. CATHARINA makes an effort.
Tanneke showed you what needs to be done? The laundry and so on. She has barely more experience of this situation than GRI
Yes, Madam. The shopping when you want. (A beat) And the studio... CATHARINA’S face tightens instantly.
This is only a trial, nothing is settled yet.
GRIET follows CATHARINA through the house, carrying a mop cloths and bucket. CORNELIA darts up the stairs ahead of
Outside the STUDIO CATHARINA stops, catching her breath. waits in silence. CATHARINA stares at the closed door. CO tugs at her skirts.
Cornelia, go down. But when CORNELIA ignores her CATHARINA makes no further She seems trapped, helpless. A finger twists and twists i hair. Rovember 2003  12

I.. My husband... You are to clean in there. (A beat) Go in. Go in! Hesitantly GRIET sidles past them and opens the door. Ins a heavy curtain she must push aside. CORNELIA tries to fo but CATHARINA grabs her back as if from the edge of a cli
Now GRIET is inside, looking out. CATHARINA is stuck in t doorway, holding back the curtain, CORNELIA glowering at side.
You must disturb nothing, leave all just as it is. Griet holds her mop and pail in the middle of the room, n wanting to start while CATHARINA watches.

Well, open the shutters. You can’t work in the dark. GRIET moves from window to window pulling open the heavy shutters, sunlight floods into the room. Downstairs the B starts crying, CATHARINA pushes her curls back impatientl

He must not be disturbed. (A beat) It’s important. With these words, almost a plea, CATHARINA closes the doo Left alone GRIET looks round the STUDIO. It is large and uncluttered, unlike the rest of the house. Clean palettes brushes laid neatly on a table, a tall cupboard, a half-o deor through into a storeroom. In one corner a table covered with a blue cloth, an open the tools of a lady’s toilette laid out in careful disarr wocden lay figure (artist's dummy) draped in a bright yel satin jacket. The picture setting. Very carefully, anchoring her hand on the corner of the t GRIET lifts the letter, dusts the cloth underneath and re it. She uses her fingers as she did with her father's clo moving along methodically, fixing, lifting and cleaning. A sudden flash of movement alarms her. Then she realises mirror, fixed on the wall above the table. She stares at herself. The light from the window makes her skin glow; s looks beautiful, transfigured. She turns away, embarrasse November 2603  13 She avoids the painting for as long as she can. It is not But at last she has to look. A woman stands gazing into the mirror as Griet did, trans her pearl necklace forgotten in her hands. The light fall softly on her profile and on the objects littering the ta artful disarray. Her yellow satin mantle seems to glow. GRIET stares, eyes wide in wonder. A chuckle. GRIET swings round to find a LADY watching her from the d She wears a stiff-bodiced black dress encrusted with shin beadwork and a wide white collar. Under her starched cap eyes are shrewd and amused. Instinctively GRIET pulls her own cap forward. MARIA THIN chuckles again, puffs on a pipe she is holding in tobacco stained fingers.
That's right, girl. You keep it to yourself in this house. In spite of herself GRIET looks back at the picture.
You‘re not the first to forget your manners in front of his paintings. GRIET curtseys, a mumbled “Madam”.
Master Van Ruijven‘s wife. MARIA THINS rakes the room with sharp eyes, gathering information.

It's like enough - though I never saw so much in her. GRIET looks from the painting to the setting. Although th objects lie on the table in the same way, the map on the and the window are almost the same, the effect is not.
It’s all... different. More... MARIA THINS nods her head, then sighs.
Should have asked more for it too. Do you think it finished? GRIET studies the painting. It certainly looks finished. THINS laughs harshly. November 2003  14
Three months already. Another three before he’s satisfied, no doubt. GRIET’S eyes widen in surprise. Suddenly MARIA THINS is a
Get along, girl. You’re not paid to stand gawping all day. GRIET hurriedly gathers up her cleaning things.

The courtyard is hung with white sheets, drying in the su GRIET is cleaning silverware, her hands and apron are bla tarnish, the cups and bowls beside her sparkle. She makes reflections dance across the walls for the children (also handed) to run after. The GIRLS laugh and squeal, the BABY gurgles and tumbles them. CORNELIA is quickest, her red-gold hair brilliant in the sunshine. She leaps after the will-o-wisp of light.

I'll catch it! GRIET too is fascinated by the light, white flame across white cloth, pale orange on the red brickwork, dazzling a window. Through the glass she catches a movement in the room abov iight flickers over the MASTER’S face. GRIET lets the bowl drop from her hand, confused. She wan pull her cap forward but her hands are dirty. The girls f silent at once, CORNELIA glares.
You made us! GRIET crouches to pick up the bowl. When she dares look u the window is empty. The girls have disappeared.
(Whispering) Lisbeth? Aleydis? Giggles from amongst the sheets. GRIET searches among the to find LISBETH and ALEYDIS happily making filthy hand pr the clean sheets.

Stop that! November 2003  15 Seeing GRIET'S face ALEYDIS stops at once, old enough to better. LISBETH still thinks it's a game. GRIET pulls asi another sheet to reveal CORNELIA. The sheet is smeared wi grime.
It’s dirty now. CORNELIA makes another hand print and laughs. In response slaps her, sharp on the cheek, a black smirch over the re CORNELIA’S eyes widen in shock but she doesn’t cry.
MAERTGE and CORNELIA accompany TANNEKE and GRIET towards grand fagade of the MEAT MARKET; stone ox heads over the classical entrances.

The Meat Market is bustling with housewives and maids buy Meat. Porters carry bloody carcasses along the sawdust~st aisles. TANNEKE leads the way importantly to one of the s stalls, where the meat has been laid out with gruesome wi wreath of kidneys round a calf's head, a flower in its ha ear. PAUL, the BUTCHER, watches them coming with a shrewd
What have you got for me, Tanneke?
Paul. This is Griet, the new maid. She will fetch the meat now, With an effort GRIET looks away from the jaunty calf.

So Griet, what takes your fancy? Nothing's too good for this family. PAUL winks at her. He is a handsome man with greying fair and a broad, cheerful face. GRIET hesitates, looks to TAN TANNEKE counts off the order on her stubby fingers.
An ox tongue and a dozen chops.
In the book again? TANNEKE nods curtly, she hates this conversation. PAUL la holds out the slab of tongue to MAERTGE and CORNELIA.
What d‘you think girls? Best tongue in Delft, eh? November 2003  16 He sticks his own tongue out, MAERTGE and CORNELIA giggle looks at the chops going into her pail, pulls one out, ho sniffs it.
This is not fresh. The Mistress wont like it. The butcher looks at her in surprise, TANNEKE goes red. G holds the meat out stubbornly. A long moment then PAUL sm broadly.

Pieter! A young man comes over, wiping his hands on his apron. He tall and broad-shouldered like his father, with golden cu easy smile. GRIET blushes and tightens her grip on the sh pail as he looks at her then his father.
Get the parcel on the cart.
But that’s for.. (Mistress Van der Velde.) His father frowns. PIETER shrugs and brings over a parcel PAUL unwraps and holds out to GRIET. She inspects the mea curtly.
That's better. TANNEKE turns away crossly. Father and son exchange an am approving glance,
We'll see you again, Griet.
GRIET is sweeping the hall when she suddenly stops. Frame the doorway she sees a MAN unloading a narrow wooden box. and dark, like a child’s coffin. VERMEER supervises from stairs.
Carrying her cleaning things Griet cautiously goes into t studio.

The room is just as usual except that on a table, placed the easel would normally stand, is the strange wooden box November 2003  17 GRIET begins her cleaning, but her curiosity is too stron her. She goes over to the strange box, a faint pretence a cleaning it as she examines it.
You want to look into it? GRIET jumps back guiltily at the disembodied voice. VERME laughs and swings down from a trapdoor in the attic.
A camera obscura. The strange words mean nothing to GRIET but she is curiou looks into the box, making adjustments. Satisfied, he ste back.
Look into the glass. GRIET moves jerkily forward and looks down at the glass p inside the box. She sees nothing.

Put this on. Over your head. VERMEER takes his heavy cloak and gently drapes it over h enveloping her in darkness. Like a jewel, an image is the the dark, The painting, minute and perfect in glowing col Only the real woman is missing. GRIET steps back in confusion, the robe falling to the fl Her face is flushed, she drops to her knees grabbing at t cloak.
I’m sorry, sir. I‘ll clean it straight away. VERMEER takes it carelessly.
Never mind that. What did you see? Griet Swallows. His questions seems to be asking for more mere facts.
I saw the setting. He starts to fiddle with the box, adjusting angles. GRIET fascinated.
But... November 2003  18
Hmm?
How did it get in there? VERMEER smiles. It is as though the sun is shining on her
I was amazed when I first saw it. He beckons her forward to look into the box beside him.

Beams of reflected light from the corner pass through this lens and are bent onto the glass plate here. GRIET strains to understand. With both of them leaning ov box the image can be faintly seen, a ghost. GRIET puts he fingers on the glass.
Is it real?
It's an image - a picture made of light. He starts to shut up the camera. GRIET is intrigued.
Does the box show you what to paint? VERMEER laughs, not unkindly.
It helps. She frowns, confused. He is watching her now.
You clean the table, Griet. Why are the things set on it as they are?
For the lady. To look as if it were her dressing table.

More than that... VERMEER moves impatiently, she wishes she knew the answer wants. Suddenly he strides across the room and removes th silver bowl, stands the powder brush on its bristles. GRI startled; it's a kind of sacrilege to disturb the setting November 2003  19

Now, look again. He holds the cloak over them both so that as they bend ov screen their faces are lit by the image on the glass. She intensely conscious of his face next to hers, he is inten what he sees. She makes herself concentrate. The image is there again, this time without the silver bowl at its cen
(hesitant) It's darker. And the brush pokes up at the end. A faint sound of approval from VERMEER.
The line is broken... You can see.

GRIET wakes with a start. It is dark, a spill of light fr trapdoor above. Wild SHRIEKS fill the house. GRIET tumbles up the steps, still tying her apron, to fin TANNEKE in the kitchen, blowing on the fire, agitated.
There you are. Fetch some water, will you. (Muttering) Blessed Mary, Mother of God... More SCREAMS from the Hall, MARIA THINS’ calming voice.
(hiding her fear) Six babies. Why does she have to make such a racket?
GRIET pumps water from the cistern, cold water splashing the metal pans, not loud enough to drown CATHARINA’S groa
GRIET hides on the steps, hands over her ears.

The CHILDREN crowd around their MOTHER and the new BABY ( on the bed. CATHARINA is radiant, pink-cheeked and smilin TANNEKE looks proud and pleased, holding up little JOHANN see his new brother. A PRIEST rattles through a blessing, MIDWIFE clears away bloody cloths. GRIET brings wine, hes in the doorway. November 2003  20

Put it on, Papa! You must. There. VERMEER crawls out from the embrace of his daughters. He wearing a little velvet “paternity” cap decked with ribbo face is flushed, hair and clothes rumpled and messy. MARIA THINS taps with her cane, startling GRIET, who stan aside at once. MARIA THINS watches her daughter and famil wry smile. She has a folded note in her hand.
Take this invitation to the house of your master’s patron, Pieter van Ruijven.

A boat ferries GRIET towards an imposing Renaissance mans one of the grandest houses in town. VAN RUIJVEN'S business occupies the quayside, a prosperou commercial bustle. The boat noses into the boathouse. INT. VAN RUIJVEN’S GREAT HALL DAY VAN RUIJVEN reads the letter, holding it up to the light the window. He is richly dressed, with longish dark hair moustache hiding a weak mouth and chin.

So, finished at last. And the baby too. Jan's brood mare. Hot-tempered is she, your mistress? Hard to handle? He looks up from the note and runs his eyes over GRIET, s blatantly lascivious that GRIET cannot stop herself from blushing. She pulls the points of her cap forward. VAN RU laughs.

She wants an answer, you'll have to wait. He goes over to a carved desk, finds a quill and paper. G gazes around the Hall, far grander than Vermeer‘s with se Vermeer paintings among others on the walls.
A very pretty picture. VAN RUIJVEN is eyeing her. GRIET looks down in silence. H pours wine from a porcelain jug.
Are you thirsty? GRIET is shocked, tries to hide it. Novenber 2003  21
No, sir.
I wouldn’t tell. He smiles conspiratorially.
No, sir. He drinks and wipes his moustache, glances at CATHARINA's
Hm, "Honoured guest". It was the old woman's idea to combine the birth feast and the viewing, no doubt. She's a tight fist. He scrawls his reply and blots it as he talks.

I'm not turning out for small beer and biscuit, tell her. This brat and I deserve a proper feast. It's time they made a show, let the world know their worth. You have very wide eyes. What do they call you?
Griet.

Your Master's a fine painter, Griet. Finest in Delft, though I shan’t tell him so. He has painted me. Perhaps that will be my epitaph. He laughs at his own joke; a rich, powerful man of the wo GRIET has never met anyone like him.

Come, take a look. He draws back the curtain to reveal a painting by his des GRIET has to move a step or two closer to look at it, clo him too. The painting, by Vermeer, is a drinking scene: in the for a young woman in a gorgeous red dress (the WOMAN from the Tavern) smiles towards us, while a gentleman (VAN RUIJVEN her a glass of wine. Behind them in a shadowy corner anot man, head on hand, is bored or asleep.
Look at that dress, you can almost stroke the satin. And the wine winking through the glass. It stank mind you, sour as vinegar by the end of each day - I had to send out for more. November 2003  22
My back ached, her hand shook so much he had to put the napkin there to save the dress. GRIET looks at the painting, drinking in the detail, fasc VAN RUIJVEN stands too close.

Can you see yourself in such finery, my dear? She loved it you know: lace and satin tight against her plump little bubbies, heavy silk on her thighs, the gentlemen looking at her. My God, she was happy.
(Offering her wine again) Sure? VAN RUIJVEN leans towards her in conscious imitation of h painted self. She shakes her head.

It's a moral lesson, of course. There's Temperance in the window holding the reins; the peeled fruit, her silly smile, mouth gaping - only one way things can end. He is right by GRIET now. She takes a step back.
The letter for my Mistress? VAN RUIJVEN drips scarlet sealing wax onto the back of th letter, presses his signet ring onto the molten blob.
Take care, it is hot. He holds out the note, so she must tug it from his plump, fingers. Behind them the painting of VAN RUIJVEN and the
She thought she was somebody, all dressed up like a lady.
The kitchen is full of smoke and steam as TANNEKE cooks, assisting her.

Green as grass, mind you. Only worked there a few months before Master van Ruijven brought her over for the painting. Got her into his wife's finery, poured wine down her like he was forcing a goose, took her home the long way. Sure enough she was carrying his by-blow before the paint was dry. November 2003  23 She slams down the meat dish with a clang.
He thinks we don't know how to celebrate a birth, does he?
LINEN, CROCKERY, CUTLERY, PEWTER are all whisked out of c or cupboards: washed, scrubbed, polished, ironed.
GRIET scours the front door step with furious energy.
TANNEKE tips jellied meat out of a mould, puts it in the STOREROOM alongside rows of other delicacies
GRIET hangs laundry to dry, including a fine CHRISTENING
MEN bring in furniture and hangings, their muddy feet mar the door step. GRIET scrubs it again, her back aches.
MUSICIANS tuning their instruments: FIDDLE and DRUM and P CATHARINA plays a melody on the fiddle, the others follow

head_text.subj: INT. ENTRANCE HALL/MARIA THINS ROOM DAY

text: More deliveries: baskets of FLOWERS and GREENERY. MARIA T takes money from her cash box for the umpteenth time. She it shut. BANG, BANG at the door.
GRIET goes to answer the back door. Everything aches and hand she puts up to the latch is cracked and bleeding.
PIETER the butcher grins at her. GRIET stares back blankl stupid with tiredness.
Why are you here? PIETER laughs. November 2003  24
A nice greeting! When I brought the meat order just for you. He gestures to a laden handcart behind him. GRIET hides h hands under her apron.
Better carry it through.
Not even a smile for my pains?
Not today.
Come on. She shakes her head.

I'll put it in the book, then? Owed by Griet - one smile. GRIET smiles at last but at that moment PIETER straighten formally, his open face clouds, his hand automatically ta his cap. GRIET turns and sees VERMEER watching from the d interior, his grey eyes running past her to PIETER before disappears inside. GRIET bites her lip.

Lights blaze from the windows. Torches are set high on th to light the street. GUESTS arrive, the rustle of rich ma and glitter of jewels. Already the house is crowded, a br thrum of voices over the MUSIC. VAN RUIJVEN and his entourage arrive by boat.
A pig spit-roasts in the backyard, a SMALL BOY sleepily t the handle. GRIET re-fills wine jugs from a barrel, carries them into house.

The remains of a banquet are spread out on long trestle t in the Hall, the fruit of TANNEKE’S labours - and of most bakers, pastry chefs and grocers of Delft. GRIET serves w VERMEER sits at one end of the table, VAN RUIJVEN at the with CATHARINA beside him. November 2003  25 She wears her green velvet dress, fat pearls gleam at her and ears, her blonde hair is piled high and held in place beautiful tortoiseshell combs, inlaid with mother-of-pear is still big from the pregnancy but there is a lightness her now, her eyes darting this way and that, her laughter over the other voices, that makes it hard not to look at The bundle that is the new BABY is passed from GUEST to G along the table until he starts to yell in protest, when handed back, with much laughter, to his mother. CATHARINA over him gently, soothing him with a finger, but the WET- is standing by. Reluctantly she hands him over, the baby on greedily to the breast.
Lucky whelp. Where's mine? CATHARINA laughs bravely as he eyes her cleavage. MARIA T rises to her feet and taps a glass for quiet.

Friends and neighbours, our honoured guest Master Van Ruijven, Mistress Emilie. Not only are we gathered tonight to celebrate the safe delivery into this world, God be praised, of little Franciscus- (Cheers and applause) Qur thanks to you all for so many kind presents - but also to rejoice at another birth: a new Masterpiece from the hand of my son-in-law, Johannes Vermeer. She pulls the cover from the finished painting, which is easel by the table. More applause, warm and genuine. No d that his talents are admired but VERMEER can only manage formal smile of acknowledgement. VAN RUIJVEN gets to his and bows, taking the plaudits as his by right. He walks this way and that before the painting, studying a great air of connoisseurship until the room falls quiet wife EMILIE VAN RUIJVEN (the subject of the painting), MA THINS and CATHARINA wait anxiously on his judgement. Only VERMEER sits still, shielding his painting hand with the
Is this Indian yellow? Vermeer nods.
Extracted from the urine of sacred cows fed only on mange leaves. You've glazed my wife in dried piss, eh? General laughter. November 2003  26
It is the right colour. CATHARINA flashes a look at her husband: Play the game. S motions GRIET to pour more wine.
(Smiling) I cannot bear the suspense a moment more, Master Van Ruijven. Pray tell us what you think. VAN RUIJVEN takes a stance in front of the painting, authoritative, proprietorial.
I like it better when the sitter looks out from a painting - takes one’s eye, so to speak. Hmm His sharp eyes flick over the worried faces of VERMEER‘S womenfolk. He smiles graciously.

Still, it is good. The colour and perspective true, the illusion perfect. Such skill lavished on my dear Emilie. Why it is almost as if she were thinking. VAN RUIJVEN laughs. MARIA THINS leads more applause - of RUIJVEN'S approval and discerning taste - as VAN RUIJVEN a heavy purse on the table in front of CATHARINA. EMILIE passively - her husband is cruelly accurate - as GRIET po wine for her.
(Quickly) And have you considered a subject for your next commission? We cannot expect you to give up Emilie for so long again.
Considered - it’s already in hand. Didn't I tell you? A coming fellow from Amsterdam. A palpable shock of disappointment from CATHARINA and MAR THINS. VAN RUIJVEN chats on, enjoying their discomfort.

Trained with Rembrandt Van Rijn, though who hasn't these days. A Merry Company by Candlelight, candlelight being his forte. I have business there at present so it suits me well. And he takes a deal more care of his sitters than some painters I could name. Fresh coffee and cakes aplenty, good company and no stinting the wine flask. November 2003  27 MARIA THINS signals for GRIET to refill VAN RUIJVEN’S gla

So, what will you daub next, Jan? Have you found inspiration up in that room of yours? Is there another patron in Delft with pockets as deep as mine? An expectant silence. But there is no other patron and VA RUIJVEN knows it. The silence grows awkward.

For pity’s sake you tell him, Master Van Ruijven. I swear I bring forth babies with less moaning than he the notion for a painting. General laughter. VAN RUIJVEN stops GRIET, a hand on her grins down the table at VERMEER.
Here's what to paint. VERMEER smiles politely.
I'd keep her company of course, offer my advice.
Griet. The wine. VAN RUIJVEN lets her go.

Look at her, man. How hard can it be to paint a pretty girl? VERMEER glances at GRIET. GRIET is in turmoil; hating the attention yet hoping, in spite of herself, that he'll see something in her. But his eyes slide away.
I have not found a subject. CATHARINA struggles to put on a brave face.
Are you in this new painting, Emilie? EMILIE opens her mouth, as if she might speak.
The company is not fit. Besides she likes to stay home. November 2003  28
Rain drives along the canal and splatters the window pane GRIET hurriedly pulls them closed from within.

LISBETH and ALEYDIS stare glumly out of the window at the pouring down; they both have racking coughs. CORNELIA is clacking the pieces on a tric-trac board, MAERTGE is tryi amuse the toddler JOHANNES with pat-a-cake games. CATHARI paces to and fro failing to soothe the BABY.
Cornelia, stop that noise. GRIET leaves quietly.

GRIET can still hear CORNELIA arguing with the others downstairs. The perpetual, thin wailing of the BABY. She the door, pulls the curtain across. The STUDIO is bare and cold. Only one thing has changed. canvas sits blank on the easel.

GRIET carries her pitchers to the canal. A few doors down street BAILIFFS are hauling furniture from a house. A SER comes out after them, holding her apron to her face. TANN come to see what‘s going on.
What is it?

Bankrupt. Three ships lost in a month they say. The shame. GRIET watches wide-eyed as more fine possessions are drag and loaded onto a barge. An old GENTLEMAN and his white-haired WIFE come slowly ou the house. Stupefied by their misfortune. The OLD WOMAN t intervene to save some personal memento, a BAILIFF pushes eff roughly so she falls to the ground. TANNEKE crosses herself, warding off evil.
God save us all. Watch out for Young Mistress — she hates to hear of money troubles. She'll turn spiteful at this, you mark my words. November 2003  29
TANNEKE, GRIET and the CHILDREN are eating their supper i apprehensive silence. The front door opens and shuts. At once CATHARINA’S VOICE rises in complaint, a string of accusations.
It's late and the two servants sit by the fire.
One year it got so bad they had to sell some of her jewels. TANNEKE rolls her eyes in delicious horror at the memory.

Phew! You can imagine how that pleased her. She went off like a thunderclap, crashing all over the house - I kept my head down I can tell you. Smashed half the china off the dresser, even went to spoil one of his precious paintings. Well, he’s a temper on him too, for all he's so quiet. She's never set so much as a foot in the studio from that day to this. GRIET listens, open-mouthed.

The household has gone to bed. GRIET lingers by the dying of the kitchen fire. When she hears the door she gets up. VERMEER comes in quietly, his cloak wrapped around him ag the freezing night. His eyes meet GRIET'S for a moment be she looks down and he goes upstairs.
GRIET in her best lace collar. MARIA THINS counts out sma coins into her hand. Far off a church bell ringing, then another.
Off to tell them all about us, eh.
GRIET returns through the gates and over the bridge to th poorer quarter. Home. November 2003  30

GRIET kneels beside FRANS between her FATHER and MOTHER. church is a modest place. GRIET'S FATHER holds GRIET’S hand, caressing the callused cracked fingers. A movement in the doorway. She looks up and sees PIETER.
The family and PIETER outside the church.
Father, Mother. This is Pieter, our butcher's son. The family’s butcher.
Sir, Mistress. I am glad to meet you. He pauses politely but none of the family are able to tak the conversation. He smiles encouragingly.
I've lived in Delft all my life and not seen the half of it. So I thought to visit every church in the City and find the best.
And how do you like ours?
Very well. So well I may stop my search here — if you'll let me, Mistress. He addresses himself entirely to GRIET’'S MOTHER, who is by his good looks and good manners.
(Laughing) By all means. Will you walk with us a little, Pieter? (They walk a few steps) So, a butcher. That's a good trade.
Griet is the hardest to please of all our customers.
Aye, she gets that from me. GRIET is annoyed at the knowing smile that passes between MOTHER and PIETER. FRANS elbows her. November 2003  31
(To FATHER) There now I forgot! We must speak with Willem Jansson. Griet, you go on with Pieter here. She whisks her husband and son away, leaving GRIET facing grinning PIETER.
Ah, Griet. Where's that smile you owe me, when I‘ve been so clever as to track you down. GRIET refuses to be impressed.
You had nothing better to do. The GOSSIPS are watching them, a handsome young man is no to pass unnoticed. GRIET takes the arm he offers, holds h up as she walks away.

Walking by the canal. There are other courting couples - that’s what they must be - prayer books under their arms, home slowly. PIETER skims a stone. It bounces and bounces the flat water, far beyond what seems possible. PIETER la turning back to GRIET, arms wide.
My lucky day. GRIET’'S arms are folded but she cannot resist answering smile with her own.
GRIET looks round the empty studio, wanting to do somethi stretched canvas is as blank as before, the room bleak. S pulls back the last shutter, mottled cold light on the wa
GRIET finds CATHARINA with her mother by the fire, heads together, talking in low voices. CATHARINA glares at GRIE annoyed at the interruption.
What is it?
About the studio, Mistress.
Yes? November 2003  32 CATHARINA rocks the baby’s cradle, to show she is not bei idle.
Should I clean the windows? CATHARINA rolis her eyes.
You don’t need to ask me such stuff.
Only it may change the light. CATHARINA pauses, considering this. MARIA THINS smiles wr CATHARINA notices.
(Sharply) Of course wash them.

Hard at work GRIET wrings out her cloth in a basin of wat wipes the windows. There are patterns of coloured glass, light stains her fingers as she works; pale blue, rose pi same look of absorbed pleasure as when she cut the vegeta She is startled when she turns to rinse the rag and sees standing stock still in the doorway.
I’m sorry sir, I-
Stay as you were. GRIET stands still, the rag in her hands. That small impa gesture of his hand.
Just now. At the window. Awkwardly GRIET tries to go back to wiping the window. He at the rag.
Drop it. She lets it fall. Dirty water splatters on the clean floo After a moment she pushes the rag under her skirt with on Looks at her left hand again. A sudden laugh of delight f VERMEER.
You can go. November 2003  33

GRIET takes down laundry, frozen stiff into scarecrow sha From inside the thin keening of the BABY stops for a mome GRIET breathes in relief, vapour curling from her lips. T starts again, GRIET tenses. CATHARINA calls her.

It is gloomy in the big room even with candles lit. A sma burns in the wide grate. The BABY grizzles fretfully, ref to feed from the WET-NURSE. CATHARINA is at her desk but she looks exhausted, nerves She frowns at GRIET as if she can’t remember why she is h
You called me? Something in the appearance of the maid; her scrupulous neatness, her starched white cap, her blatant youth, is d galling to CATHARINA.

The child needs a draught. (To herself) My mother will not be content till one of them dies from her meanness. (To GRIET) You will go to the apothecary. An errand CATHARINA always reserves for herself.
Me, Madam?

I suppose I should do everything! But I have to stay with the baby and besides it’s cold and I believe I am falling sick too. (Impatiently) I will write what to ask for. CATHARINA pushes aside loose papers to make space. Some f the ground and GRIET hurries to pick them up. Columns of figures, accounts, bills: CATHARINA snatches them back.
Can you read? GRIET hesitates, her head dipping under the cap.

I can follow my prayer book. CATHARINA smiles. Starts to write; a big, bold hand, dipp quill fast and splashing drops of black ink across the pa She sands and folds the paper with a flourish. November 2003  34
Coltsfoot elixir, hyssop and elderflower. Enough for both boys. You will need... She looks through the desk for money. Finds only a few co
(agitated) No, no, that's not it! To go on the Master's account. She hands the note to GRIET, flushed with indignation.
Anywhere away from a fireside is bitterly cold. GRIET shi she puts on her wooden pattens, wraps her rough woollen s tighter round her shoulders. The room darkens.
Griet. She spins round. VERMEER has followed her in to the narro space. He puts a hand out, as one might to calm a frighte animal, then lets it fall.
Sir?
It’s very cold. She waits, tense at the sudden strangeness.
Will you get something for me too? VERMEER hands her a scrap of paper.
Some colours. He knows.
On your account, sir? VERMEER is taken aback for a moment.
Yes. My wife need not know. The exchange feels conspiratorial, guilty, reinforced by dark and narrow space. He touches the edge of her shawl.
(Vaguely) This is too thin. I have a cloak- November 2003  35

Can I come? VERMEER shakes his head, coming out of the moment. He tur abruptly and pushes past CORNELIA who is peering inquisit GRIET tucks the paper into her shawl quickly, but not fas enough to avoid CORNELIA’S sharp eyes.
No. It's too cold.
What's that? GRIET bites her lip.
I have to get medicines for your brother. You don’t want to get sick too. But the evasion - the lie - hangs between them. CORNELIA’ narrow, cat-like, accusing.
You better hurry. We had a brother that died.

A single skater pushes a sled-barrow down the frozen cana hunched against the biting wind. GRIET hurries along dese streets. INT. APOTHECARY‘S DAY Three steps down into the gloom of the apothecary’s shop. shakes the snow off her shawl and looks around: the first she has ever been in such a place. All around the walls glass bottles and jars are filled wi liquids or packed with dried herbs. A desiccated lizard d in mid-air. The atmosphere is smoky from a grumbling peat
Well? GRIET is startled. Peering into the corner by the fire sh a tiny old man, as brown and wrinkled as one of his remed is watching her curiously.

My Mistress, Catharina Bolnes, sent me. The baby is sick. She brings out the note and the old man scans it quickly starts getting down different jars and bottles, weighing herbs in his scales. November 2003  36

You must be the new maid. She spoke of you, I guessed you were pretty. Is she expecting again, that she sent you? This weather, eh. GRIET watches his quick hands working, crushing and mixin dried leaves.
Cold cures where it don't kill. The APOTHECARY ties up the packages neatly.
There. My best regards to your Mistress. And Master Van der Meer. GRIET reaches into her shawl and pulls out his paper.
The Master... The APOTHECARY opens it and finds VERMEER’S instructions. frowns at GRIET.
He always gets this himself. GRIET meets his eyes, blank to their prying.
The weather.

Hm. With another suspicious look at her he climbs a ladder to cupboard and unlocks it with a key chained to his belt. C the pigments are the most precious things in his shop. He out dark glass jars, sealed with wax, stands them on the counter.
A year's wages couldn't buy you these. GRIET stares at the mysterious raw materials of magic.
(approving) He wants the very best, it's all that matters to him.
Bitter cold weather, the wind whips snow flurries along t frozen canals. Even so, one window is open up in the stud November 2003  37

At first we see only over the model's shoulder; VERMEER painting, his face rapt with concentration. Moving round camera reveals one of CATHARINA’S bodices, blue striped w yellow, then GRIET‘S white cap. But the model is not GRIE Another GIRL, pale and thin, stands in the same pose, enc asexually in CATHARINA’S clothes.
GRIET is mopping the floor on hands and knees when MARIA black cane pins down her cloth. GRIET looks up, startled. old woman studies her, a thin smile.
He's started a new painting. But you know that.
Yes, Madam. MARIA THINS is watching her sharply.
There's no buyer, he wont even let me see it. But he's working again... It usually takes longer. CORNELIA runs in through the front door, dirty footprints clean floor.
Grandmother, Aleydis won't give me- MARIA THINS cuffs her sharply.
See what you've done, silly child! Now Griet must do it over. CORNELIA scowls at GRIET. MARIA THINS softens.
There, poppet, get along and don't sulk.
Going to bed GRIET sees that her things have been disturb tile has been deliberately broken in half, she and Frans either side of the jagged edge. She is very upset. November 2003  38

While the other girls bend diligently over their cushions bobbins CORNELIA teases a kitten with the dangling thread her lace work. GRIET, with a pile of mending before her, to concentrate. The kitten’s claws snag in the delicate t CORNELIA laughs.
You'll spoil it.
I don't care. She gets up, letting the cushion fall on the floor, pins bobbins scattering.
Pick it up.
No. The other CHILDREN are watching round-eyed. Gentle MAERTG to make peace.
(Pleading) Cornelia. CORNELIA sneers at GRIET.
You don’t tell me what to do. You're only a servant. GRIET gets up angrily and CORNELIA, scared and excited, h behind the furniture.
Go away! Leave me alone! I didn't do anything. CATHARINA comes hurrying in, the BABY asleep in her arms. CORNELIA runs to her, clings to her skirts as if for prot
What’s the matter? There is no answer, except CORNELIA’S plaintive snivels. CATHARINA pets her distractedly but the BABY has woken an starts crying again. CATHARINA glares at GRIET.
What's wrong with you? Be off about your work. November 2003  39

GRIET sees with relief that the STUDIO door is open. She inside and leans against it, shutting out the hostile wor noise and clatter of everyday life. It is not till she is steps into the room that she realises VERMEER is there, s and still on his painting stool.
I’m sorry, sir. He waves her into silence, concentrated on his painting.
Stay. GRIET waits awkwardly in the middle of the room.

The lead-white needs re-filling from the cupboard. GRIET opens the door revealing jars, pouches and pots of different pigments. She takes one of the larger pots and Measures out white paste into the small dish on the table VERMEER seems to pay no more attention to her. She stands watches, enthralled, as he mixes and thins the paint on t palette, making marks with a sure hand. GRIET stares at the chilly MODEL standing uncomfortably a window, trying to see what he sees. She looks back at the and then, seized by an inspiration, she goes quietly to t cupboard. She looks through the jars until she sees the o wants. VERMEER comes over to the mixing table to re-fill his pal with white. He sees the other colour.
I didn’t ask for blue.
Her skirt. I thought-
(Cold outrage) Put it away. He turns back to the easel. She is left at the table hold little pot of blue. November 2003  40
GRIET walks along a parapet, at the end PIETER must jump down. They are in a corner sheltered by a bridge. He keep of her waist, slides one hand up to her neck.

(Tender) Griet. He moves closer, she tries to push him away, he laces his fingers through hers. She focuses on his hand: dried bloo at the base of the nails. He smiles at her, starts to lif side of her cap.
Let me see your hair. She pulls the cap down, he tugs it up again, laughing.
What colour is it? She pushes him off.
(Lying) Brown.
Straight or curly?
(A beat) Neither.
Long? Very long? He tries to pull off the cap again. She beats at his arms deadly earnest.
No! He sees she is serious, lets his hands drop. She straight cap in silence.
It was only a game.
Mother will expect me home. PIETER grins.
She knows where you are. November 2003  41 GRIET shoots him a look of fury, outraged at the truth an of it.

GRIET cleans the picture setting, buffing the silver jug, reflection distorted in the gleaming metal. She compares setting to the painting. Areas are blocked in dark colour jug and bowl are red-brown, the girl’s skirt is black. Du dead colours.
Griet. VERMEER is behind her, his dark reflection overwhelming h the jug. He can't apologise, turns instinctively to the p for support.
Were you looking at it? GRIET nods.
Well? GRIET hesitates, then blurts out her confusion.
I don’t understand. Nothing is the right colour.

Like the blue skirt? This is the base colour, it gives the tone, the shadow and light. When it's dry I glaze over with blue, but thinly so the black shows through. VERMEER walks to the window and opens it wide.
Look, Griet. Look at the clouds. She steps to the window, he moves aside but still close e to feel the warmth of his body. She stares intently at th clouds and blue sky.
What colour are they? She frowns, it must be some kind of trick. Wants to speak dare not. That impatient gesture.
White? November 2003  42 She knows it was the wrong thing to say and can see he is to dismiss her.
No, not white. There are colours in the clouds. Blue, yellow, grey.... He smiles.
Yes. Now you understand. She doesn't, but she doesn’t want to admit it. She steals glance at him, his sombre face aglow.
Forget how the world is meant to be. Only look beneath. In the shadows. Words frustrate him.
(A command) Look, Griet.
GRIET stares out of the high kitchen window at scudding c a pewter jug forgotten in her hands.

Thinking about your butcher boy? She laughs, not unkindly, as GRIET blushes and goes back polishing the jug. EXT. DELFT STREETS/APOTHECARY’S SHOP - DAY GRIET slips away from the Market stalls down the alley to Apothecary's shop.
GRIET creeps up the stairs and slides through the studio
VERMEER is sitting, massaging his painting hand as he sta the painting, no brush or palette to be seen.
(at length) sir? She holds out the little packages from the apothecary. He back at the drab reds and browns of his painting, already what will be there. Novenber 2003  43
Did you get the lapis? GRIET finds a small lump of blackish stone (lapis lazuli)
For the skirt. (An afterthought) You can mix the colours. GRIET is excited, but also fearful.
Mix the colours? He is already pulling open his painting cupboard, taking scallop shells, a wide copper bowl.
Sir, I haven't time. All the chores-
Make time.
In here, sir? With you? VERMEER makes his impatient gesture, then realises what s saying.
No, no. Upstairs. Come. In a corner of the studio is a wooden ladder leading up. climbs up swiftly, leaving GRIET alone. Hesitating a mome picks up the bowl and dishes and clambers after him.

A bare, bright room. The only furniture is a heavy table stone top, dipped in the centre and a cupboard with many drawers. VERMEER lays out the pigments with deft, delicate fingers powders and unpromising lumps of ore.

Cochineal..cinnabar..indigo..burnt umber.. Lapis lazuli. He hangs over them with the helpless love of the obsessiv GRIET watches in fascination. He fishes narrow strips - “buckles” - of lead from a jar brown liguid. They are furred with white powder which he into a dish. November 2003  44
Lead-white. A dark mash of grape skins and pips is spooned into the c bowl.
This will make verdigris. From one of the packages he takes little black sticks.

Bone black. You grind it with the muller, like this. He takes a smooth egg-shape stone from the table, puts a of charred bone into the dip and quickly grinds it to a f powder. Deftly he spoons it into a shell.

Now, you try. He puts another piece of bone in the hollow. GRIET picks muller and tries to do as he did. She finds it awkward, t stone slips in her hand, the bone flakes out of the hollo VERMEER watches her intently.

Twist from the shoulder. He puts his hand over hers. At the shock of his touch she freezes, her breath and his in the silence. His white hand on hers, outlined against black powder. The seconds stretch. She recoils abruptly a muller skids from her grasp across the table.

GRIET sneaks through the house in the blue-grey before da Through the room where TANNEKE and the WET NURSE are snor The BABY starts to cry and the WET NURSE stumbles out of the HALL, TANNEKE moans at her. GRIET shrinks into the sh as the disturbance spreads among the sleepers all around
She climbs the stairs. Stops outside the studio door and above the frame for a hidden key.
GRIET grinds and refines colours, sieving the ground dust through a muslin, absorbed in her work. November 2003  45
GRIET helps TANNEKE fold sheets into the linen cupboard. yawns theatrically.

Lord, I‘m that tired I can barely stand. CATHARINA is preparing to go out, she is in high spirits. jewel box is open and she wears a wide white linen collar protect her rich yellow mantle from her face powder. The are hanging around her, CORNELIA trying on her necklaces.
Be careful, pigeon.
How much longer is the wet nurse to be with us, Mistress? CATHARINA doesn’t look round from the mirror.

I don’t know. A month or so. Cornelia, no! Not my pearls. CORNELIA puts back a heavy pearl necklace, takes an inlai tortoiseshell comb from the jewel box. MAERTGE smoothes h mother’s elaborately dressed hair, helping to pat the cur place round her forehead. TANNEKE sighs again.
A month! Or more! CATHARINA dangles a bright chain over the BABY’S crib fon laughing as his fat fingers grab for it.
Ah, ah, greedy! (To TANNEKE) Franciscus is taking his rusk now but he still needs milk. Why? What is it to you?
Oh nothing. She's eating us out of house and home for a start...
She must eat well - for the baby.

All I'm saying is, I can't cook twice as much and have no sleep at all. It’s more than a body can stand, to be woken all hours by her coming and going. November 2003  46 CATHARINA holds up her pearl earrings and approves hersel a smile.
